thread.title: Former M&S boss heads pro-EU campaign in forthcoming referendum
thread.title_full: Former M&S boss heads pro-EU campaign in forthcoming referendum - Mirror Online

author: Jack Blanchard
title: Former M&S boss heads pro-EU campaign in forthcoming referendum
text:
One of Britain’s most respected business chiefs been unveiled as the head of the campaign to keep Britain in Europe.
Lord Stuart Rose, the former boss of Marks and Spencer, will chair the ‘In’ campaign for the coming EU referendum.
The business chief warned Britain that a vote to leave the EU would be a “leap into the unknown”.
“Most people, myself included, will make a hard-headed, practical calculation on what is best for the British people. I believe that Britain is stronger in Europe,” Lord Rose said.
“The choice in the coming referendum is between remaining stronger, safer and better off inside Europe, or taking a leap into the unknown - risking our prosperity, threatening our safety, and diminishing our influence in the world.”
Lord Rose was widely credited with turning around the fortunes of M&S during his seven-year spell as chief executive between 2004 and 2011.
Getty Background: Lord Rose is credited with reviving M&S
His appointment is a major coup for the ‘In’ campaign, which launches formally on Monday.
“He brings unparalleled experience of business and enterprise to our board,” beamed the campaign’s executive director Will Straw, son of the former Labour Foreign Secretary Jack.
“He knows the value that Britain’s membership of the EU brings to businesses right across the UK, and what would be at risk if we left.”
The appointment of Lord Rose - who was made a Tory peer last year - is a blow to the various ‘Out’ campaigns which say leaving Europe would be good for British business.
It also a boost to David Cameron , who is almost certain to campaign for Britain to stay in the EU.
Reuters Tensions: Angela Merkel is said to be frustrated with Cameron’s vague negotiations
The PM has pledged to hold the In/Out referendum before the end of 2017 following a renegotiation of Britain’s relationship with Europe.
To that end Mr Cameron hosted German Chancellor Angela Merkel at Chequers for dinner for crunch talks on EU reform.
Mrs Merkel is understood to have grown increasingly frustrated at the PM’s failure to spell out his exact demands for a new-look Europe.
“Germans like to know exactly what the details are. Then we can tick the boxes – we’ll do this, this and this,” a source close to the Chancellor said.
“But the British are remaining vague, and we’re not making any progress. Soon the UK Government will have to make up their mind.”
